review_title: Good Place to work. Feel a little underpaid for what I do
job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Visalia, CA
pros: The majority of people I work with are great! The university is always understanding with time off and they include generous paid vacations and holidays.
cons: The pay should be higher. I feel like if they don't start paying people more there will be more and more people leaving to go work somewhere else.

pros: Good people. The staff have great hearts.

pros: People are awesome and familial.

pros: The people and culture here are incredible: the values and collegiality are filled with grace. I truly love where I work. Students receive individual attention from faculty and are truly mentored here at Fresno Pacific University.
cons: Those not used to higher ed may find it a difficult transition from the business world, which is much faster-paced.

pros: A Christian environment with opportunities to further your education, nice co-workers, beautiful grounds, holidays off, non-smoking environment, and the opportunity to meet people from different cultures
cons: The college pays very poorly and requires every employee to work not only their own job, but adds "other duties as assigned" to your job description, which ultimately means you are required to hold several other people's job duties as well.

review_title: Wholesome place for now, but intellectually mediocre
pros: By far the best thing about Fresno Pacific University is the wholesome campus environment. The students are very nice and respectful. The Office of Spiritual Formation, under Angulus Wilson, is crucial here, holding weekly services for students on Wednesday that keep the school's Christian identity lively and strong, even if a corrosive liberalism has gone far towards compromising the Christian faith of many of the faculty. There are strict rules about student conduct, which I don't agree with in detail (e.g., on alcohol) but which help to maintain the wholesome environment. Combined with a physically attractive campus, with a fountain and quads etc., Fresno Pacific is quite a pleasant place to work.
cons:
When I was in grad school, I had serious doubts about whether I'd ever find an academic job, but I took for granted that if I did find one, the intellectual environment would be scintillating. I expected that a lot of clever colleagues, who could understand and take an interest in my ideas, would sit down at the lunch table every day to hone our knowledge.

With these perhaps quixotic expectations, my disillusionment upon coming to Fresno Pacific was extreme. Not once in my years at Fresno Pacific did I have a conversation with colleagues whose intellectual level reached that which I routinely enjoy on Facebook, on blogs, or in conversations with my highly academic family. One or two of my colleagues were shockingly indifferent to ideas and the life of the mind. Others had a favorable attitude to it, but no habits of rigor or intense curiosity. Nor did I meet anyone at Fresno Pacific who could come close to understanding my academic research, or who took an interest in it, and I very rarely met anyone who seemed to have an active research program that they cared to talk about.

The other con, from my perspective at least, is that the wholesome environment seems unlikely to last. The president is wonderful and may yet hold the line, but the faculty's commitment to Fresno Pacific's Christian values is very shaky.

review_title: It has been a blessing to work for an organization that is changing the lives of so many students.
pros: There is always something fun happening on campus.  The benefits are good and the school is continuing to grow.
cons: Base salaries are low, like most non-profit organizations.  However, between the Holidays and generous leave plans there is plenty of time off to manage work life balance.

pros: There is nothing to say pro. The review makes me write 20 words, so that's why I am going on for no reason.
cons: Everything is wrong, they had a horrible assistant directors; they were all in a click and were lazy people. I hope this is 20 words

job_title: Food Server in Fresno Crossing, CA
pros: Sense of community on campus really has a connection between everyone you serve a day.
cons: School always being a pressure, many people call out all the time or flake on covering your shift and you have to take the fall for that

review_title: A supportive and encouraging work environment
job_title: Student Office Assistant in Fresno, CA
pros: Wonderful people, supportive & encouraging office culture, opportunity for increased responsibility, job training, weekly devotionals, work life balance
cons: The only con I can think of is that I was not allowed to stay longer. The position I held was only available for students. Because I graduated, I was no longer eligible for employment in that position.

review_title: It is a great place to invest in the lives of students!
pros: Investing in student lives, Department supervisors supportive of adjuncts, lots of opportunities in degree completion. Opportunities to build both professional and personal contacts. A good "second" job for adjuncts to give back...
cons: salary is probably on average for private university adjuncts, but is a bit low....

review_title: Great University as a Student and Employee
pros: FPU is concerned about staff input and allows staff to take charge of their own situations to improve on the experience for employee and student.
cons: There truly is not a con about working or studying at FPU. Seriously!
